Aha! So, seems Linux has no problem with that, but Mac does.

Hyper calls shutdown if there's Close header in the request. The response is also sending a Close header, and so shutdown is called a second time in the response. I assumed it'd be a no-op if it was already closed...

issue.title: Normalize calling tcp.shutdown multiple times across OSes

labels.name: A-docs
labels.description: Area: Documentation for any part of the project, including the compiler, standard library, and tools

repository.name: rust
repository.description: Empowering everyone to build reliable and efficient software.

issue.body:
Calling `tcp.shutdown(how)` multiple times will return different values, depending on the OS. On Linux, it returns `Ok(())`, on OS X, it returns `ErrorKind::NotConnected`.

Perhaps this behavior could be made to be the same across platforms. If not, at the least, the docs should call it out.

Noticed from https://github.com/hyperium/hyper/issues/508

/cc @aturon @alexcrichton

issue.title: fix(net): ignore NotConnected error in NetworkStream.close
issue.body:
On OSX, calling shutdown a second time will return a NotConnected error.
This commit will just ignore it, since we can agree that if a stream is
"not connected", it is in fact "closed".

Closes #508 

/cc @wezm

---

I couldn't decide whether to use conditional compilation to only do this on OSX, but eventually figured the reasoning in the commit message.
